description: Borrowed from Middle French problématique, from Late Latin problematicus, from Ancient Greek προβληματικός (problēmatikós), from πρόβλημα (próblēma, “outjutting, barrier, problem”), from προβάλλω (probállō, “I throw, place before”), from πρό (pró, “before”) + βάλλω (bállō, “I throw, place”). By surface analysis, problem +‎ -atic.

adjectives.description: problematic (comparative more problematic, superlative most problematic)

definitionGroups.group: Posing a problem; having or suffering from problem(s):

entries.meaning: Difficult to overcome, solve, or decide.
examples: However, estimating what consumers will pay in the future is problematic.

entries.meaning: Not settled, uncertain, of uncertain outcome; debatable, questionable, open to doubt.
examples: it portends a problematic future for the movement

entries.meaning: (sociology) Contributing (especially if subtly) to discrimination (such as racism, sexism, homophobia, transphobia, or ageism).
(logic, dated) Only affirming the possibility that a predicate be actualised.
(chiefly in the plural) A problem or difficulty in a particular field of study.
